items.message:
Flooding is expected in this area. This means properties are at risk of flooding.
Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have.

The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels.
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Further heavy rainfall is forecast throughout today, 28/12/2022, will cause lake levels to remain high. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water. Flooding is possible on the Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. Further rainfall is forecast throughout this week and the weekend. Lake and river levels are high and may rise further, the risk of flooding to low-lying land remains. We are continuing to monitor the forecast and will issue the flood warning if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Due to industrial action, we will be temporarily automating our messages, this message cannot be updated during this time.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message: River levels are rising at the Bradford on Avon river gauge due to recent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed. Further rainfall, sometimes heavy, is expected from today, Wednesday 28/12/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. Refer to local authority website for local road closures. From 17:00 on 28/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
There is no longer a threat of flooding at the present time, though standing water and debris may still remain.  Today, Monday 02/01/2023, and tonight, are forecast to be dry. Further rain is forecast on Tuesday, 03/01/2023. The catchments remain wet and we continue to monitor the situation. The forecast rain will be monitored by our system to see if a new flood alert is needed on Tuesday. 
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  

River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. Further light rainfall is possible today, however, this is not expected to cause any flooding. The weather will remain unsettled for the rest of the week, with heavy rainfall possible on Wednesday. We will be monitoring the situation closely and issue further alerts if necessary.

Our incident response staff are carrying out routine inspections on the river and clearing any blockages.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message: Levels have risen in the Washford River, as a result of the rainfall overnight and this morning. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from today, Wednesday 28/12/2022, and over the coming days in response to any further rain. Flooding of low-lying land is possible from the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries. The current rain is forecast to pass through by early afternoon today, followed by some more rain tonight and showers tomorrow. Further rain is forecast for Friday, 30/12/2022, and the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and consider installing property flood resilience equipment. Please refer to local authority websites for local road conditions. Please note, from 17:00 on 28/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

Flooding is possible in this area.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels.
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

River levels remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. 
Further rainfall is forecast today, Wednesday 28/12/22, and over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain elevated.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
There is no longer a threat of flooding at the present time, though standing water and debris may still remain.  Today, Monday 02/01/2023, and tonight, are forecast to be dry. Further rain is forecast on Tuesday, 03/01/2023. The catchments remain wet and we continue to monitor the situation. The forecast rain will be monitored by our system to see if a new flood alert is needed on Tuesday. 
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

Flooding is possible in this area.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels.
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message: The River Yeo at Huish Episcopi pumping station remains high and the drain levels are still high. There is flood water on the surrounding fields and low-lying land. Further rainfall could lead to an increase in these levels, and local low-lying roads may be affected. Please refer to the Check for Flooding pages on Gov.uk for information on river levels. The rainfall today, Wednesday 28/12/2022, has passed through and further rain is forecast tonight, followed by showers tomorrow. Additional rain is forecast for Friday, 30/12/2022, and the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low-lying roads and footpaths near local watercourses. Please refer to local authority websites for local road conditions. Please note, from 17:00 on 28/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

River levels are likely to remain high in the Lower Dorset Frome due to the heavy rainfall this morning.  Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham.  River levels are high and forecast to rise further.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  From 17:00 on 28/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated.  We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: The flood alert is now in force for the Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby. Flooding is possible for the tidal foreshore and agricultural land adjacent to the river in the Cawood, Kelfield, Wistow and Selby areas. River levels are forecast to rise on the river Ouse due to persistent rain through Wednesday, 28/12/2022. Further bands of rain are forecast over the coming days, which may cause river levels to remain high. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Visit the GOV.UK website to see the current flood warnings, view river and sea levels or check the 5-day flood risk forecast.

River levels remain high but steady at the Brimscombe river gauge as a result of recent rainfall, consequently flooding of roads and farmland may continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Elmore to Sharpness. Other locations that may be affected include Chalford, Leonard Stanley and Cambridge. We expect river levels to remain elevated for the next few days and potentially impacted by additional rainfall forecast today Wednesday 28/12/22 and over the next few days.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent, prolonged rainfall. Levels will continue to rise over the next few days and flooding of fields and some minor roads is expected.  Further rainfall is expected over the coming weekend. Due to a BT fault data from the Woodyates borehole is currently unavailable online, however today's reading is 93.95 metres above sea level.
Looking further ahead next week will be relatively dry, but with the possibility of stormy conditions appearing at the end of the week.

Flooding is expected in this area. This means properties are at risk of flooding.
Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to the recent rainfall across the area and have risen at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected within the next few days by flooding from groundwater.

We expect levels to rise slowly over the next few days. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message tomorrow (03/01/2023), or as the situation changes.
